Final project results: Outcome 1: 11 (cumulative) NAP-Ag contributed to strengthening national capacities on climate change adaptation and agri-culture. As a result, 5,200 decision makers from 11 countries learnt new skills. Their capacities to identify and appraise adaptation options, using tools such as multi-criteria assessment, cost-benefit analysis, impact evaluation, and vulnerability and risk assessment to facilitate evidence-based decision-making in their NAPs process were strengthened. Strategic capacities to advance adaptation planning and implementation have also been reinforced, including on gender main-streaming, climate finance, mobilisation, and monitoring and evaluation of adaptation. A Massive Online Open Course (MOOC) on Building Climate Resilience in Agriculture was developed as a joint effort between FAO, UNDP and UNITAR (https://napmooc.uncclearn.org). Over 1,000 partic-ipants completed the course, which is still available as self-paced learning. All course material is available as an online toolkit.
Outcome 2.1: 60 (cumulative) Outcome 2.2: 3 completed, 3 partially completed Colombia, Guatemala, Kenya, the Philippines, Thailand, Uganda, and Uruguay adopted key na-tional strategic frameworks on climate change, agriculture and development with support from the NAP-Ag programme. In Colombia, the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development (Ministerio de Agricultura y Desarrollo Rural – MADR) finalised the Integral Management Plan of Climate Change (Plan Integral de Gestión del Cambio Climático - PIGCC) for the agricultural sector. In Guatemala, the Strategic Plan for Climate Change of the Ministry of Agriculture, Livestock and Food (MAGA) for 2018-2027 and Action Plan for 2018-2022 were published. In Kenya, the programme support-ed the formulation, consultation and launch of Kenya’s Climate Smart Agriculture Strategy (2017-26) and its Implementation Framework (2018-2027). In the Philippines, the programme contributed to the ambitious revision of the Agriculture and Fisheries Modernization Plan (AFMP). In Uganda, the process of developing a NAP for the Agriculture sector has been completed. In Uruguay, the programme supported the formulation of the NAP for Climate Change and Variability for Agricul-ture (PNA-Agro), and the 2025 Action Plan, led by Ministry of Livestock, Agriculture and Fisheries (MGAP). In Thailand, the programme supported the Ministry of Agriculture and Cooperatives (MoAC) to implement the Agricultural Climate Change Strategic Plan (2017-2021) by using im-proved prioritisation and budgeting of sectoral adaptation actions and a roadmapto accelerate the integration of adaptation into the agriculture sector.
The programme supported climate public expenditure reviews and activities related to climate sen-sitive budgeting. In Nepal, the Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock Development (MoALD) final-ised a methodology for climate budget coding and expenditure tracking for the agriculture sector, which will be adopted into the budget by the Ministry of Finance (MoF). In the Philippines the pro-gramme supported the Department of Agriculture (DA) in the identification of the interventions that can be tagged as climate action/expenditure. In the Gambia, a sensitisation workshop on climate-sensitive budgeting was conducted for key national stakeholders and a feasibility assessment on conducting a climate expenditure review for the Agriculture and Natural Resources sector was finalised. This was followed by the development of a briefing note on challenges, opportunities, and recommendations relevant for climate budget tagging and climate expenditure tracking. Public expenditure analyses were conducted in Guatemala, Kenya, and Uganda. At the global level, a study titled A review of Domestic Data Sources for Climate Finance Flows in Recipient Countries (UNDP and GFLAC, 2018) was published to strengthen understanding data sources on domestic climate finance in six NAP-Ag countries including, Colombia, Guatemala, Kenya, Nepal, the Philip-pines, Zambia.
Additionally, the NAP-Ag programme supported countries to identify NAP-NDC linkages related to their agricultural sectors, for instance through collaboration with the NDC Partnership (NDC-P) and its new initiative, the Climate Action Enhancement Package (CAEP). Six NAP-Ag countries have requested and received support to enhance their NDCs: Colombia, Gambia, Guatemala, Uganda, Uruguay, and Viet Nam. Greater integration with partners working on NDC implementation helped to streamline technical support to countries working towards enhancing or updating their NDCs. Nine NAP-Ag countries received support to enhance their NDC through the NDC Enhancement Support, established under this programme.
Guidance for policymakers and practitioners on adaptation planning in agriculture, including ca-pacity development, cost-benefit analysis, and gender mainstreaming were released (more details in Section 10). Among these, Addressing Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries in National Adapta-tion Plans – Supplementary Guidelines in English, French, Spanish and Russian are considered key.
Outcome 3.1: 10 The programme aimed to strengthen evidence-based decision making in partner countries by building capacity for the appraisal of adaptation options and for the M&E of adaptation in agricul-ture. Trainings on impact evaluation, cost-benefit analysis and multi-criteria analysis were held in Kenya, Uganda, Uruguay, Thailand, Viet Nam, and Zambia. A manual on impact evaluation for adaptation planning in the agriculture sectors based on the NAP-Ag experience is being finalised. Case studies on the impact evaluation work undertaken in Uganda, Zambia and Thailand are be-ing developed. The programme also supported the identification of indicators to be used as met-rics to track adaptation, resilience, and adaptive capacity for the agriculture sectors in Nepal, Thai-land, Uruguay, and Viet Nam, as well as the development of M&E frameworks for the agricultural sector in Colombia, Guatemala, Kenya, the Philippines,Thailand, Uganda and Uruguay. The guid-ance note, Strengthening M&E Systems for Adaptation Planning in Agriculture Sectors along with a training package, were published in 2019 and delivered in several countries.
Outcome 4.1: 11 national exchange consultations (closing workshops and national workshops on lessons learned); good practices and lessons learnt on adaptation shared Outcome 4.2: 42 international/ regional events The NAP-Ag programme contributed to the UNFCCC processes and in particular to the implemen-tation of the Paris Agreement, and its Article 7 on Adaptation. It also contributed to the work of the NAP Technical Working Group at the UNFCCCC and provides input into the discussions of the LEG on accelerating the formulation and implementation of NAPs. It has established key partner-ships with UNFCCC entities to highlight the unique insight and experience of working with agricul-ture and environmental focal points in 11 partner countries. Aside from providing inputs to the LEG and the NAP Technical Working Group, it participated actively in the Koronivia Joint Work on Agriculture through the provision of experiences from NAP-Ag countries. In terms of global out-reach regarding the UNFCCC process, the project supported the LEG work and the Adaptation Committee, the Thematic Working Group on Agriculture, Food Security and Land Use under the NDC Partnership. Furthermore, the programme worked closely with the UNFCCC Focal Points at country level as well as the African Group of Negotiators Expert Support (AGNES) on measuring adaptation progress in agriculture. Real-time information on the NAP-Ag initiative was provided on the FAO NAP-Ag website and UNDP Adaptation Portal.
A communications strategy, including targeted messaging and operational plan, was established to effectively underpin the programme’s objectives. Additionally, a communications toolkit on adap-tation was developed and distributed to country focal points with the aim to provide practical guid-ance to enhance national outreach and visibility of activities on the ground. The main platforms for programme news and updates were the dedicated FAO and UNDP NAP-Ag websites. Articles on country activities, results and events were drafted and published on a regular basis. Knowledge products including publications, videos and infographics were developed and disseminated widely internally as well as via external channels and partners’ platforms.
During the duration of the programme, NAP-Ag featured at a number of international events, such as the COP, both as organisers of side events and as panel speakers in event’s hosted by part-ners. The programme also organised a series of webinars to facilitate discussions on technical topics related to the integration of the agriculture sectors in national adaptation planning, along with other partner institutions, such as the Least Developed Expert Group (LEG) and the UNDP/UNEP NAP-Global Support Programme (NAP-GSP).

Outcome 3: 10 (cumulative) Zambia: The Impact Evaluation of Climate Information and Early Warning Systems was docu-mented and disseminated through events for sensitization of relevant national stakeholders. The case study is under finalisation. Kenya: The KCSAIF M&E framework was developed and validated, it will serve to track KCSAIF progress and performance, and be tested n pilot counties in Kenya as part of the GCF NAP Readiness Project. Uganda: Implementation of the Uganda Agriculture NAP framework will be guided by a Per-formance Monitoring and Evaluation Framework (PM&EF) that was developed in conjunction with the NAP for Agriculture. The PM&E Framework will be integrated in the national M&E system for adaptation. The baseline data for the PM&EF were collected in 2019. A case study on impact evaluation is under finalisation. Viet Nam: A monitoring and evaluation (M&E) system and indicators for adaptation in the agriculture sector was developed and piloted in five of Viet Nam’s eight agro-ecological regions. An online reporting system and M&E guidelines were developed, in preparation for incorporation into MARD’s overall M&E system. Nepal: The M&E framework was developed through the identification of CCA activities (143), outputs (31) and outcome indicators (42) outlined in the ADS based on a survey with 108 officers in all provinces. A training manual on Agriculture Sector CCA Result M&E Framework was finalized. Philippines: The M&E System and Plan for the Agriculture and Fisheries Modernization Plan were developed. Thailand: The M&E framework and key performance indicators identified for Thailand’s Agri-culture Climate Change Strategic Plan for 2017-21 (ACCSP) and NAP was developed. Uruguay: The process of identifying a set of indicators to be used as metrics to track adaptati-on for the agricultural sector in Uruguay was concluded. Colombia: The indicators of the M&E framework were identified, but its design and imple-mentation are still pending. Guatemala: A platform for the Monitoring, Evaluation and Reporting (MER) system and rele-vant indicators for the Agriculture, Livestock and Food Security sector of the National Action Plan on Climate Change has been consolidated.
